earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD, MIM 242650) is characterized by recurrent infections of the respiratory tract due to reduced mucociliary clearance and by sperm immobility. Half of the affected offspring have situs inversus (reversed organs), which results from randomization of left-right (LR) asymmetry. We previously localized to chromosome 5p a PCD locus containing DNAH5, which encodes a protein highly similar to the Chlamydomonas gamma-dynein heavy chain. Here we characterize the full-length 14-kb transcript of DNAH5. Sequence analysis in individuals with PCD with randomization of LR asymmetry identified mutations resulting in non-functional DNAH5 proteins.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Olbrich H
earliestArticle.dc:title: Mutations in DNAH5 cause primary ciliary dyskinesia and randomization of left-right asymmetry.

evidence.dc:description: Distribution of DNAH5 in human respiratory cilia was analyzed by immunofluorescent staining in both healthy control patients and in patients with DNAH5 mutations.  DNAH5 staining is observed throughout the respiratory ciliary axoneme in healthy patients. In addition DNAH5 staining is seen in the microtubule organizing centers, the apical perinuclear region and in cytoplasmic compartments that connect the two. Respiratory epithelial cells from patients with ODA defects and homozygous mutations (F373, F658, and UNC7, PMID:11788826) were analyzed by immunofluorescent staining.  DNAH5 proteins were undetectable in the ciliary axonemes of these patients but instead accumulated at the microtubule organizing centers. DNAH5 is expressed but unable to localize to the ciliary axoneme.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous disorder characterized by recurrent infections of the airways and situs inversus in half of the affected offspring. The most frequent genetic defects comprise recessive mutations of DNAH5 and DNAI1, which encode outer dynein arm (ODA) components. Diagnosis of PCD usually relies on electron microscopy, which is technically demanding and sometimes difficult to interpret.
dc:source.dc:creator: Fliegauf M
dc:source.dc:title: Mislocalization of DNAH5 and DNAH9 in respiratory cells from patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia.

evidence.rdfs:label: DNAH5 mislocalization in PCD patients with DNAH5 mutations

evidence.dc:description: Murine Dnahc5 is expressed exclusively at the mouse LRO during early embryogenesis. Whole mount in situ hybridizatition analysis of murine Dnahc5 (orthologous to human DNAH5) in early-gastrulation stage mouse embryos (7-8 days post coitum) indicates that Dnahc5 is restricted to the LRO node.  Laterality defects (situs inversus) linked to DNAH5 mutations in humans may result from immotile LRO monocilia with defective outer dynein arms.  The nodal expression of Dnahc5 in a mouse model is consistent with this hypothesis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Early embryonic expression of murine Dnahc5

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization analysis of murine Dnahc5 expression in the developing and adult respiratory system of mice shows ciliated epithelial expression in the whole bronchial system (embryonic nasopharynx, larynx,  trachea and adult lung). This murine expression pattern is consistent with the PCD phenotype of humans with mutations in DNAH5.

dc:source.dc:creator: Kispert A
dc:source.dc:title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in PCD patients carrying DNAH5 mutations.

evidence.rdfs:label: Murine Dnahc5 expression in upper & lower respiratory system

evidence.dc:description: Patient F718-II1 caries compound heterozygous mutations affecting splicing at the 3' end of the gene (C-terminal mutation). One variant alters a canonical splice acceptor site located at the boundary of intron 75 and exon 76. In silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts the variant will lead to splice site acceptor loss. The other variant alters a canonical splice donor site located at the boundary of exon 75 and intron 76. In silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts this variant will lead to splice site donor loss. Immunofluorescent staining of DNAH5 in respiratory epithelial cells from the patient shows that mutant DNAH5 is absent from the distal part of the ciliary axonemes but still detectable within the proximal part, as well as in the microtubule organizing centers. This pattern indicates that at least one of these DNAH5 variants is still targeted to the site of proximally located ODA complexes.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is characterized by recurrent airway infections and randomization of left-right body asymmetry. To date, autosomal recessive mutations have only been identified in a small number of patients involving DNAI1 and DNAH5, which encode outer dynein arm components.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hornef N
dc:source.dc:title: DNAH5 mutations are a common cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia with outer dynein arm defects.

evidence.rdfs:label: Mislocalization of mutant DNAH5 in PCD patients

evidence.dc:description:
High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating in human DNAH5 mutants shows a range of effects on cilia motility depending on the particular variants.   Phenotypes can range from completely immotile respiratory cilia to altered motility with stiff movements and low amplitudes (Raidt et al PMID:25186273).

There was no significant change in ciliogenesis or cilia length with Dnah5 knockdown.  However, approximately half of the ciliated cells were immotile. Where motile cilia were present, the ciliary beat frequency was normal, though some motile cilia exhibited dyskinetic ciliary motion (Supplementary Video S6 and S7).

dc:source.dc:creator: Zahid M
dc:source.dc:title: Rapid Ex-Vivo Ciliogenesis and Dose-Dependent Effect of Notch Inhibition on Ciliogenesis of Respiratory Epithelia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Dnah5 siRNA knockout in mouse tracheal epithelial cells

evidence.dc:description:
Left-right flow at the gastrocel roof plate (GRP) is impaired in Xenopus dnah5 morphants, suggesting that dnah5 is required for the ciliary motility underlying leftward flow during embryogenesis. DNAH5 variants in humans are also associated with impairment of laterality determination.  Olbrich et al (PMID: 11788826) show that DNAH5 mutations in humans cause  primary ciliary dyskinesia and randomization of left-right asymmetry, linking aberrant ciliary ultrastructure and motility to laterality defects in humans.  
Similarly, Dnah5mut/mut mice have been found to lack outer dynein arms on embryonic LRO monocilia, resulting in immotile cilia, impaired flow at the LRO, and randomization of Nodal signaling with normal, reversed or bilateral expression of key molecules (NÃ¶the-Menchen et al PMID:31638833).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Leftward flow of extracellular fluid breaks the bilateral symmetry of most vertebrate embryos, manifested by the ensuing asymmetric induction of Nodal signaling in the left lateral plate mesoderm (LPM). Flow is generated by rotational beating of polarized monocilia at the posterior notochord (PNC; mammals), Kupffer's vesicle (KV; teleost fish) and the gastrocoel roof plate (GRP; amphibians). To manipulate flow in a defined way we cloned dynein heavy chain genes dnah5, 9 and 11 in Xenopus. dnah9 expression was closely related to motile cilia from neurulation onwards. Morphant tadpoles showed impaired epidermal ciliary beating. Leftward flow at the GRP was absent, resulting in embryos with loss of asymmetric marker gene expression. Remarkably, unilateral knockdown on the right side of the GRP did not affect laterality, while left-sided ablation of flow abolished marker gene expression. Thus, flow was required exclusively on the left side of the GRP to break symmetry in the frog. Our data suggest that the substrate of flow is generated within the GRP and not at its margin, disqualifying Nodal as a candidate morphogen.
dc:source.dc:creator: Vick P
dc:source.dc:title: Flow on the right side of the gastrocoel roof plate is dispensable for symmetry breakage in the frog Xenopus laevis.

evidence.rdfs:label: Morpholino knockdown of Xenopus dnah5 disrupts lateral flow

evidence.dc:description: Xenopus model only address left-right laterality defects phenotype of human PCD

Mdnah5 deficient mice in this study lack outer dynein arms, exhibit cilia immotility, random left-right specification, chronic respiratory infections, respiratory distress, and hydrocephalus.  This mouse model has most of the pathological phenotypes associate with primary ciliary dyskinesia 3, with or without situs inversus.  DNAH5 associated PCD is not usually associated with hydrocephalus, but  mice PCD models in general are associated with hydrocephalus so this is not an unexpected phenotype in mice. Primary ciliary dyskinesia 3 is sometimes associated with infertility, but this particular pathology was not observed in these mice, as most of them die during the first 2-3 weeks of age.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), also known as Kartagener's syndrome, is a human syndrome that results from ciliary dysfunction. This syndrome is characterized by recurrent respiratory infections, situs inversus and infertility. In some cases, hydrocephalus is also observed. We have characterized an insertional mutation in a mouse axonemal dynein heavy chain gene (Mdnah5) that reproduces most of the classical features of PCD, including recurrent respiratory infections, situs inversus and ciliary immotility. These mice also suffer from hydrocephalus and die perinatally. Electron microscopic studies demonstrate the loss of axonemal outer arms. These results show that mutations in Mdnah5 are a primary cause of PCD and provide direct evidence that mutations in an axonemal dynein can cause hydrocephalus. Mutations in the human DNAH5 have recently been identified in PCD patients. Comparison of the mouse model and the human data suggests that the degree of ciliary dysfunction is causally related to the severity of human PCD, particularly the presence of hydrocephalus.
dc:source.dc:creator: IbaÃ±ez-Tallon I
dc:source.dc:title: Loss of function of axonemal dynein Mdnah5 causes primary ciliary dyskinesia and hydrocephalus.

evidence.rdfs:label: Mdnah5 deficient mice reproduce symptoms of PCD

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC29 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10815del is a frameshift variant predicted to truncate ~22% of the protein product (p.Pro3606fs) and to trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium indicate loss of DNAH5 function.
Founder variant. Already scored this variant in a different proband (UN47 II-1).

ENST00000265104.5(DNAH5):c.232C>T is a nonsense variant predicted to truncate 98% of the protein leaving intact only the 78 amino acid N-terminal portion of DNAH5 (p.Arg78Ter) and to trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium indicate loss of DNAH5 function.
Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.

evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype mapping compatible with linkage to DNAH5 performed on affected individuals; Amplification and direct sequencing of all 79 exons and one alternative first exon of DNAH5 from affected individuals; Segregation analyses and screening of controls for mutations was done by direct sequencing or allele-specific digests
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.rdfs:label: F658 II-2

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.8440_8447del is a frameshift variant predicted to either trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~40% of the protein product (p.Lys2813_Glu2814insTer).  Immotile cilia (IC) noted by direct visualization of respiratory cilia and loss of outer dynein arms (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium (PMID: 12775878) indicate a loss of DNAH5 function.

This variant has been down-scored because of homozygosity and because the persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested. This variant was further down scored to 0.5 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNCB II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10815del is a frameshift variant predicted to either trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~22% of the protein product (p.Pro3606fs).  Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium  indicate loss of DNAH5 function.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10815del (p.Pro3606fs) is found in seven families in Hornef-Group of PCD Families (UNC47, UNCB, UNC29, OP19, UNC35, UNC102, and UNC74) and has been identified as a founder mutation by haplotype analysis.  It is not scored in this individual as it has been scored in proband UNC47 II-1.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC45 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.3905del is a frameshift variant that is predicted to trigger either nonsense mediated mRNA decay or truncation of ~72% of the protein product (p.Leu1302fs). Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual.

Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.  This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13458dup is a frameshift variant that is predicted to truncate ~3% of the protein product (p.Asn4487Ter). Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual.

Haplotype analysis suggests that the NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13458dup (p.Asn4487Ter) mutation is consistent with a founder mutation in some families (UNC45, UNC74, and UNC83 from Hornet-Group of PCD Families), but is has occurred independently in other families (OP40).  This variant was already scored as a founder mutation in proband 83 II-1.

evidence.dc:description: ENST00000265104.5(DNAH5):c.1627C>T is a nonsense variant predicted to truncate 88% of the protein leaving intact only the  543 amino acid N-terminal portion of DNAH5 (p.Gln543Ter).  Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium indicate loss of DNAH5 function.

Down-scoring to 1.5 was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested. This variant was further down-scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.832del is a frameshift variant predicted to truncate 94% of the protein leaving intact only the 278 amino acid N-terminal portion of DNAH5 (p.Ala278fs) and to trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium indicate loss of DNAH5 function.

Down-scoring to 1.5 was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.  This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Homozygosity mapping of a gene locus for PCD on Chromosome 5p identified DNAH5 as candidate gene and is described in Omran et al 2000 (PMID:11062149).
evidence.rdfs:label: F373 II-4

evidence.dc:description:
NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5563dup is a frameshift variant predicted to either trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~60% of the protein product (NP_001360.1: p.Ile1855fs). Although the variant is predicted to be a null mutation, persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested.
Immotile cilia (IC) noted by direct visualization of respiratory cilia and complete loss of outer dynein arms (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium (PMID: 12775878) indicate a loss of DNAH5 function.
This variant has been down-scored because of parental consanguinity and homozygosity of the variant in the proband.

evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype mapping compatible with linkage to DNAH5 performed on affected individuals; Amplification and direct sequencing of all 79 exons and one alternative first exon of DNAH5 from affected individuals; Segregation analyses and screening of controls for mutations was done by direct sequencing or allele-specific digests
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.rdfs:label: F758 II-1

evidence.dc:description:
NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10555G>C is a missense mutation predicted to replace Gly3519 with an Arg. This Glycine residue is highly conserved across species.  According to amino acid substitution tool PROVEAN, a substitution of Arginine for Glycine at 3519 is likely to be deleterious.  This amino acid substitution is within the highly conserved microtubule binding domain of DNAH5 and is highly likely to have an impact on DNAH5 function.
Immotile cilia (IC) noted by direct visualization of respiratory cilia indicate loss of DNAH5 function, but no electron microscopy (EM) data showing ciliary ultra structure, in particular presence or absence of outer dynein arms (ODA) was provided.

This variant was further down scored to 0 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype mapping compatible with linkage to DNAH5 performed on affected individuals; Amplification and direct sequencing of all 79 exons and one alternative first exon of DNAH5 from affected individuals; Segregation analyses and screening of controls for mutations was done by direct sequencing or allele-specific digests
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC7 II-3

evidence.dc:description:
The NC_000005.10:g.13716691C>G variant alters a canonical splice acceptor site located at the boundary of intron 74 and exon 75 and in silico splicing tool SpliceAI predicts the variant will lead to splice acceptor loss and skipping of exon 75. This variant is predicted to produce a protein with a C-terminal mutation (p.Ser4304As pfsTer6). Splicing mutation is reported to have been confirmed for this variant with RNA data by Hornef et al 2006 (PMID 16627867).
Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual. 54% of ODAs appear shortened and in general were reduced in number (PMID:12775878).
Ciliary beat reported at <1 Hz with limited range and movement appears uncoordinated in high-speed video microscopy.

This variant was further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: OP31 II-1

evidence.dc:description: The NC_000005.10:g.13865667C>T variant alters a canonical splice donor site located at the boundary of exon 26 and intron 27 and in silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts the variant will lead to splice site donor loss. High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed that most respiratory cilia were immotile, but some showed severely altered motility with stiff movements and low amplitudes.

Not scored as loss of function despite the prediction of aberrant splicing, as there is no mRNA or protein evidence of exon skipping or frame-shifting. This variant was further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5563dup is a frameshift variant predicted to trigger either nonsense- mediated mRNA decay or truncation of ~60% of the protein product (p.Ile1855fs). High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed that most respiratory cilia were immotile, but some showed severely altered motility with stiff movements and low amplitudes.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5563dup is found in three families in Hornef-Group of PCD Families (OP31, UNC72, UNC76) as well as in previous studies (Olbrich et al., PMID:11788826) and has been identified as a founder mutation by haplotype analysis. It has been scored as an Olbrich et al. variant.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC47 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10815del is a frameshift variant predicted to either trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~22% of the protein product (p.Pro3606fs).  Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium indicate loss of DNAH5 function.

Down-scored because while the variant is predicted to be a null, persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested. Further down-scored because the variant is in a homozygous state in the patient.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC34 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5482C>T  is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger either nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncation of ~61% of the protein product (p.Gln1828Ter). Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual suggest loss of DNAH5 function.

Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested. This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10226G>C is a missense variant predicted to produce a protein product with a deleterious substitution of Trp 3409 for Ser (amino acid substitution tool PROVEAN). Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual suggest loss DNAH5 function.

This variant was at 0.5 because an in silico prediction of  the deleterious effect of an amino acid substitution is not sufficiently strong evidence of functional impact.  This variant was further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC83 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13458dup is a frameshift variant predicted to truncate 137 amino acids (~3%) at the C-terminal end of the protein product (p.Asn4487Ter) and to trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of respiratory cilium  indicate loss of DNAH5 function.

Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.  In addition, the variant is in a homozygous state in the patient.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: F718 II-1

evidence.dc:description:
The NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13338+5G>A variant alters a canonical splice donor site located at the boundary of exon 75 and intron 76. In silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts the variant will lead to splice site donor loss.   

Immunofluorescent staining of DNAH5 in respiratory epithelial cells from the patient shows that mutant DNAH5 is absent from the distal part of the ciliary axonemes but still detectable within the proximal part, as well as in the microtubule organizing centers.  This pattern indicates that this DNAH5 variant is still targeted to the site of proximally located ODA complexes (this data will be scored in Experimental section). High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed reduced mobility that was of limited range, uncoordinated, and had a frequency max of 1-2Hz.

Variant was not scored as loss of function despite the prediction of aberrant splicing, as there is no mRNA or protein evidence of exon skipping or frame-shifting.  However, this variant was upscaled to 0.25 due to the recurrence of the variant in another proband (UNC76 11-1) that has a reported ODA defect (published in Hornef et al. 2006 (PMID: 16627867).
Haplotype analysis of this proband indicates that this variant, NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13338+5G>A, is likely a founder mutation.  This variant was identified in more than one unrelated PCD family (PMID:11788826).

The NC_000005.10:g.13714622T>A variant alters a canonical splice acceptor site located at the boundary of intron 75 and exon 76. In silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts the variant will lead to splice site acceptor loss. 

Immunofluorescent staining of DNAH5 in respiratory epithelial cells from the patient shows that mutant DNAH5 is absent from the distal part of the ciliary axonemes but still detectable within the proximal part, as well as in the microtubule organizing centers.  This pattern indicates that this DNAH5 variant is still targeted to the site of proximally located ODA complexes (this data will be scored in Experimental section). High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed reduced motility that was of limited range, uncoordinated, and had a frequency max of 1-2Hz.

Not scored as loss of function despite the prediction of aberrant splicing, as there is no mRNA or protein evidence of exon skipping or frame-shifting.  This variant was further down scored to 0 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: OP54 II-1

evidence.dc:description:
The NC_000005.10:g.13890974A>G variant alters a canonical splice donor site located at the boundary of exon 16 and intron 17 and in silico splicing tool, SpliceAI, predicts the variant will lead to splice site donor loss. 
Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual. 
High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed completely immotile cilia in respiratory epithelial cells.

Not scored as loss of function despite the prediction of aberrant splicing, as there is no mRNA or protein evidence of exon skipping or frame-shifting. This variant was further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.7914dup (p.Arg2639fs) is a frameshift variant predicted to truncate ~43% of the protein product and trigger nonsense mediated decay of the mRNA. 
Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual. High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed completely immotile cilia in respiratory epithelial cells.

Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.  This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of 80 genomic fragments comprising all 79 and one alternative exon of DNAH5. Segregation analysis and screening of control subjects were performed by restriction analysis, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography, or sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: OP36 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.6037C>T is a nonsense variant predicted to either trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~56% of the protein product (p.Arg2013Ter). Although the variant is predicted to be a null, persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested.

The variant has been down-scored to 1 due to its homozygous state in the patient.  It has been further down-scored to 0.5 because the variant was identified as a DNAH5 defect by single gene Sanger sequencing.  In the absence of any evidence of gene impact on ODA structure or immunofluorescent data indicating loss of DNAH5 along the ciliary axoneme, the possibility exists that this DNAH5 variant is not causally linked to PCD in the proband.

evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype mapping compatible with linkage to DNAH5 performed on affected individuals; Amplification and direct sequencing of all 79 exons and one alternative first exon of DNAH5 from affected individuals; Segregation analyses and screening of controls for mutations was done by direct sequencing or allele-specific digests
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.rdfs:label: F661 II-2

evidence.dc:description:
NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.4361G>A is a missense mutation predicted to replace Arg1454 with a Gln. This Arginine residue is highly conserved across species.  According to amino acid substitution tool PROVEAN, a substitution of Glutamine for Arginine at 1454 is likely to be deleterious.

Immotile cilia (IC) were noted by direct visualization of respiratory cilia.  High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed completely immotile cilia in respiratory epithelial cells (PMID:25186273) suggesting a defect in DNAH5 function, but no electron microscopy (EM) data showing ciliary ultra structure, in particular presence or absence of outer dynein arms (ODA) was provided.  

Immunofluorescent staining of DNAH5 in epithelial cells from the proband shows absence of DNAH5 from the respiratory ciliary axonemes (PMID: 16492982).

This variant was further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

ENST00000265104.5(DNAH5):c.8910_8911delinsG is a frameshift variant predicted to either trigger nonsense mediated mRNA decay or truncate ~46% of the protein product (p.Phe2971SerfsTer12).

Immotile cilia (IC) were noted by direct visualization of respiratory cilia.  High-speed video microscopy of cilia beating showed completely immotile cilia in respiratory epithelial cells (PMID:25186273) suggesting a defect in DNAH5 function, but no electron microscopy (EM) data showing ciliary ultra structure, in particular presence or absence of outer dynein arms (ODA) was provided.

Immunofluorescent staining of DNAH5 in epithelial cells from the proband shows absence of DNAH5 from the respiratory ciliary axonemes (PMID: 16492982)

Down-scoring was performed despite the prediction of nonsense mediated decay or truncation of the protein product, as the persistence of a product has not been tested.  This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype mapping compatible with linkage to DNAH5 performed on affected individuals; Amplification and direct sequencing of all 79 exons and one alternative first exon of DNAH5 from affected individuals; Segregation analyses and screening of controls for mutations was done by direct sequencing or allele-specific digests
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of PCD was based on i) recurrent infections of the respiratory tract with development of bronchiectasis with and without situs inversus, and ii) complete lack of ciliary motility by direct visualization of respiratory cilia, and or defects of outer dynein arms on electron microscopic examination in at least one affected family member.
evidence.rdfs:label: UCL16 II-5

evidence.dc:description:
NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5130dup  (p.Arg1711Thrfs)is a frameshift variant predicted to either truncate ~36% of the protein product or trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. 
Outer dynein arm defects (ODA) seen by electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual.

Although the variant is predicted to be a null, downscoring has been performed since the persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested.  This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.1828C>T is a nonsense mutation predicted to either truncate the protein at position 610, leaving only 13% of the N- terminal portion of DNAH5 or trigger nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. Electron microscopy of cross section of cilium from the respiratory epithelium of affected individual identified outer dynein arm (ODA) defects.

Although the variant is predicted to be a null, downscoring has been performed since the persistence of a truncated protein product has not been tested. This variant was further down scored to 1 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

dc:description:
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous group of disorders, usually beginning in early childhood, characterized by recurrent infections of the upper and lower respiratory tract, randomization of left/right body asymmetry, and subfertility (PMID: 32943623). The PCD phenotype results from structural and/or functional abnormalities of motile cilia and flagella. The most frequently mutated gene (15-24% of Caucasian patients) in PCD is *DNAH5* (Dynein Axonemal Heavy Chain 5) which encodes a subunit of the ciliary outer dynein arms (ODAs) and is essential for force generation during ciliary beating (PMIDs: 11788826, 16627867, 19357118). The *DNAH5* gene was first reported in relation to PCD in 2000 (Omran et al., PMID: 11062149). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 3, with or without situs inversus is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the *DNAH5* gene. *DNAH5* variants were first reported in 2002 by Olbrich et al., (PMID: 11788826). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases caused by inherited *DNAH5* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 3 with or without situs inversus (MONDO: 0012085, OMIM #608644). 

Evidence from 17 probands in 2 publications have been included in this curation representing 22 unique variants (3 missense, 5 nonsense, 9 frameshift, and 5 splice site) (PMIDs: 11788826, 16627867). Of note, four of these variants have been identified as founder mutations by haplotype analysis: NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.10815del (p.Pro3606fs), Clin Var ID: 65636, is found in seven PCD families in Hornef et al., (PMID: 1662786). Similarly, NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13338+5G>A, Clin Var ID: 572293, is also likely a founder mutation. This variant was identified in more than one unrelated PCD family (PMID:11788826).  Variants NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.5563dup (p.Ile1855fs), Clin Var ID: 407241, and NM_001369.3(DNAH5):c.13458dup  (p.Asn4487Ter), Clin Var ID: 350995, have been identified as founder mutations that also occur independently in some families of different haplotype (PMID: 16627867). The mechanism of pathogenicity in *DNAH5* mutations appears to be bi-allelic loss of function. There is an abundance of case-level and case-control level evidence available in the literature, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points).

This gene-disease association between PCD 3 and *DNAH5* is also supported by gene expression data.  In situ hybridization analysis of murine *Dnah5* expression in the developing and adult respiratory system of mice shows ciliated epithelial expression in the whole bronchial system (embryonic nasopharynx, larynx, trachea and adult lung) (PMID: 12775878).  This murine expression pattern is consistent with the PCD phenotype of humans with mutations in *DNAH5*. Similarly, murine *Dnah5* is expressed exclusively at the mouse Left Right Organizer (LRO) during early embryogenesis, consistent with the hypothesis that laterality defects (situs inversus) linked to *DNAH5* mutations in humans may result from immotile LRO monocilia with defective outer dynein arms (PMID: 11788826). Distribution of DNAH5 in human respiratory cilia was analyzed by immunofluorescent staining in both healthy control patients and in patients with *DNAH5* mutations. DNAH5 staining is observed throughout the respiratory ciliary axoneme and in the microtubule organizing centers in healthy patients, but is undetectable in the ciliary axonemes of *DNAH5* mutant patients where protein instead accumulates at the microtubule organizing centers (PMID: 15750039). An example of disease phenotypic variability is seen in one patient with compound heterozygous mutations affecting splicing at the 3' end of the gene (C-terminal mutations), where mutant DNAH5 is absent from the distal part of the ciliary axonemes but is still detectable within the proximal part, as well as in the microtubule organizing centers. This pattern indicates that at least one of these C-terminal DNAH5 variants is still targeted to the site of proximally located ODA complexes (PMID: 16627867). 

In addition to gene expression data, there are multiple animal models available to support this gene-disease relationship, including *Dnah5mut/mut* mice that show most of the pathological phenotypes associated with PCD 3 (PMIDs: 11912187, 31638833, 33561200); mouse respiratory epithelial spheroid cells cultures with *Mdnah5* siRNA knockdown that reproduce defects in cilia motility seen in human *DNAH5* variants (PMID: 32823934); and embryonic Xenopus with morpholino *dnah5* knockdown that support the role of dnah5 in the ciliary motility underlying leftward flow during embryogenesis (PMID:Â 19450574). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *DNAH5* and primary ciliary dyskinesia 3 with or without situs inversus. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on December 9, 2021 (SOP Version 8).
